instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Hi,

Video: [MEDIA=imgur]a/x2A2qk9[/MEDIA]

I can successfully restore the BridgeOS (T2) via DFU mode but still no image on the screen, the S0 power rails are (kinda) present. I don’t think that’s a backlight issue because I have checked it with a flashlight still can’t see anything on the screen.

- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 0.6V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 0.6V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>PP0V95_S0_CPUVCCIO_REG_R</SIGNAL> = 0.95V
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58V (whcih

Note: Screen is good.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Trackpad clicking and USB-C power light on are irrelevant.
But Caps Lock light reaction confirms that the machine boots and doesn't get stuck.

Disconnect internal LCD and check again for external video.

BTW, write directly into Reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
Unless you see any reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
We try to maintain the forum aesthetic...

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Did restore, or revive in DFU?
Just in case, try PRAM reset too.

Any history fault?
Check for liquid signs on audio board (both sides) and cable.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
did restore and revive via DFU. (No problem overall)

Already tried PRAM reset, no success :/

History:
Waterdamage | Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and defect <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, fixed it. As you can see on the ampere meter the board is booting (20V/0.3-0.4A)

No water damage on the audio board (both sides). Btw why is it necessary? It should also show something on the screen without it.

edit:
I’m a little bit concerned about the voltage of the <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> …. Related to the repair wiki it should be 0.75V. (Source: [URL]https://repair.wiki/w/A1932_2018_-_2019_MacBook_Air[/URL] - power sequence) … mine is 0V.

<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL> = cant measure it .... AUTORANGE is looping on my multimeter but <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> is present....strange.

edit2:
Maybe the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7410</CHIP> or <CHIP>U7430</CHIP> are faulty?

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>:
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_IMON</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_NTC</SIGNAL> = 0.8V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_COMP</SIGNAL> = 4.6V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_FB</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_RTN</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_ISUMP</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_ISUMN_R</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_ISEN1</SIGNAL> =  0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_ISEN2</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_FCCM</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_PWM1</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_PWM2</SIGNAL> = 5V

<CHIP>U7410</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7430</CHIP>:
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_PHASE1</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_PHASE2</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUGT1</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUGT2</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_BOOT1_RC</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_BOOT2_RC</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_BOOT1</SIGNAL> = 4.6V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_BOOT2</SIGNAL> = 4.6V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_GL1</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>CPUGT_GL2</SIGNAL> = 0V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.58V

I assume <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is important for the internal GPU, isn’t it? So in my case the GPU has no power which explains the no image issue. Do you agree?

Should I start with replacing "<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>"?

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
iGPU voltage appears when high graphics load is detected.

"<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL> = cant measure it .... AUTORANGE is looping"
Never try to measure DC voltage on the coil input; an o-scope shows you why!
DC voltage is present on the output pin of the coil, where the filter cap is placed.
Sometime you can find almost the same DC reading on the input pin; depending which power supply is.
However, that is not the correct measurement point; you've just seen that.

"No water damage on the audio board (both sides). Btw why is it necessary?"
I didn't say is necessary.
But many 01521 boards get T2 damaged because of leakage from audio board/flex.
Look at pins 33 & 35 of J6100; hope you understand what I mean.
This fault was several times mentioned on the forum.

"As you can see on the ampere meter the board is booting (20V/0.3-0.4A)"
That is not 100% confirmation.
Caps Lock light reaction is the best confirmation in this case.

However, missing internal/external video at same time points to iGPU problem.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
You didn't mention <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> corrosion before!

Very likely T2 has internal damage.
Was the reason I asked about audio board and flex.
But <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> can cause same problems as the audio amplifier placed on audio board too.
T2 signal lines are placed next to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> underneath <CHIP>U6400</CHIP>.
I'm sure you will find short, or low values to ground on that lines.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Sry forgot about it.

Should I remove <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> and check for shorts or test without it?

Btw which signals are used by the T2?

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Just point one ball close to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and follow the lines in boardview.
If goes to T2 and you have an access to check it on the board, that is luck.
If not, can only be check without <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> on the board.
Was you needed to do before soldering new chip...

threads.message: <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> should be good now, as the board boots and switch to 20V on USB-C input.

- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_SPKKRAMP_AVDD</SIGNAL> = 0.328
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_AREG</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_DREG</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>I2S_SPKRAMP_L_R2D</SIGNAL> = 0.487
- <SIGNAL>I2S_SPKRAMP_L_BCLK</SIGNAL> = 0.488
- <SIGNAL>I2S_SPKRAMP_L_D2R_R</SIGNAL> = 0.499
- <SIGNAL>I2S_SPKRAMP_L_LRCLK_R</SIGNAL> = 0.488
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 0.466
- <SIGNAL>SPKAMP_L_MODE</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0.462
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_OUTP</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_OUTN</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_BSTN</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_SNSP</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_L_SNSN</SIGNAL> = OL
- <SIGNAL>I2C_SPKRAMP_L_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.467
- <SIGNAL>I2C_SPKRAMP_L_SDA</SIGNAL> = 0.467

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Are these voltages, or diode mode readings?
Multimeter shows "V" on diode mode, but NEVER write it when you post diode mode values.
Avoid confusions, please.
Also, "0V" means short in diode mode; are you sure is not OL instead?

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
Yeah sorry, I have updated my reply.
Also, "0V" means short in diode mode; are you sure is not OL instead?
- OL not 0V.

threads.title: MacBook Air (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> | <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02) - No image no backlight
threads.message:
I don't see any short, or low value.

Seems to get too many OL readings.
Did you check all them with red probe on ground?

I still suspect T2, because of corrosion between <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> balls...
